Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation Research Project: Exploring Computing Careers through a Virtual Career Fair Using Embodied Conversational Agents

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Morehouse College will conduct a research project to uncover new insights regarding the effect of culturally relevant career exploration resources on high school students' career interests. The researchers propose a mixed-methods research design using quantitative and qualitative data to examine the effects of using embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in virtual career exploration fairs with rural and urban high school students. Building on previous research that shows that ECAs are as effective as humans when used to mentor undergraduate students interested in pursuing graduate school, the researchers will explore whether the research extends to high school students considering computing careers.

Guided by the "possible selves" and "social cognitive career theory (SCCT)" frameworks, researchers will examine students' perceptions of computing and computing careers before and after each career exploration fair, noting the effect and impact of questions and answers (Q&A), storytelling, and culturally relevant storytelling. The ECAs will represent minority individuals in authentic computing professions. The specific research questions are: 1) In what ways do students' career interests and perceptions change following virtual career exploration fairs using ECAs? 2) How do culturally relevant ECAs differ based on student perceptions and identities? and 3) What roles do gender, race, ethnicity, grade level, and location (rural/urban) play in students' career identities? Survey data will be analyzed to determine the relative impact of the virtual career exploration fair on student self-efficacy, interest in computer science careers, and predictive factors of the SCCT?

The project presents a potentially sustainable solution for motivating urban and rural high-need school districts to explore computing careers. Data collected on student attitudes, interests, and self-efficacy will help guide improvements to the ECAs and ensure they are broadly applicable for future uses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant supported the development and analysis of a Virtual Computing Career Fair using Embodied Conversational agents. A portal was designed using 11 Embodied Conversational Agents (ECAs) of African American computing professionals. The goal of the portal was to see if students who utilized the portal will decide to pursue computing careers because of exposure to these virtual Black computing professionals. Schools range from rural (e.g., St. James) to Suburban (e.g., Laing) to Urban (e.g., South Atlanta). In total, 523 students participated in the quantitative study. Data showed interaction with the ECAs made no significant change in students perception about pursuing careers in computing. To help explain this, a focus group was held with various teachers who administered the tool to their students. The primary suggestion from the group was to focus on using Computing Careers Now as a tool for students already enrolled in a computing class, as opposed to students who may have no interest in pursuing a computing career. They explained the tool would assist those who are interested in computing already but may not know all of the available options. Plans for future work include targetings students enrolled in computing courses, asking more survey questions about the effect having an African American looking ECA and the addition of information regarding colleges, programs and scholarships, and access to mentoring. Another item of note is around the technology. Since the development of the proposal, the ECA technology has been replaced more and more by non-embodied conversational agents. For example, think Amazon?s Alexa or Apple?s Siri. With these interfaces, users are more focus on the intelligence of the dialogue itself, rather than the appearance of the agent. Future studies will surely include this change.

Broader impacts of the study include several African American undergraduate students who worked on the project entering computing careers and graduate programs in computing. Two students from Morehouse went on to doctoral programs in computing, one student from Spelman College went on to a doctoral computing program and another Spelman student is currently pursuing her masters in human-computer interaction. For the principal investigator (PI), this award served as his first federal grant as a PI. The extra research that was produced from this grant has led the PI to help build the research infrastructure at Morehouse College (HBCU) and help support Morehouse in producing approximately 20 percent of all the current African American male doctoral students in computing.
